questionList.title: Cor pulmonale

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Pulmonary hypertension in chronic lung diseases.

questionList.questionText:
A 19-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to a 4–5-day history of chest discomfort that radiates to the nuchal fold and shoulders bilaterally.  The patient took over-the-counter ibuprofen and had some pain relief.  She reports associated fatigue and bilateral knee pain yesterday, which has since resolved.  The patient has a history of systemic lupus erythematosus, for which she takes hydroxychloroquine.  She does not smoke or take illicit drugs.  The patient has no family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Temperature is 38.3 C (100.9 F), and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg in the upper extremities bilaterally.  Examination shows an erythematous rash over the cheeks and the nasal bridge.  Pain is not reproducible with chest palpation.  A superficial scratchy sound is heard between S1 and S2.  Breath sounds are normal.  ECG reveals sinus tachycardia at 103/min and diffuse T wave inversion.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Hemoglobin10.2 g/dL
Platelets90,000/mm3
Creatinine1.3 mg/dL

Serum troponin drawn on presentation is <0.01 ng/dL.  Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
Acute pericarditis

Etiology

  • Viral or idiopathic
  • Autoimmune disease (eg, SLE)
  • Uremia (acute or chronic kidney failure)
  • Post myocardial infarction
    • Early: peri-infarction pericarditis
    • Late: Dressler syndrome

Clinical features & diagnosis

  • Pleuritic chest pain (↓ when sitting) ± fever
  • Pericardial friction rub (highly specific)
  • ECG: diffuse ST-segment elevation & PR-segment depression
  • Echocardiography: pericardial effusion

Treatment

  • NSAIDs & colchicine for viral or idiopathic etiology
  • Variable for other etiologies

NSAID = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug; SLE = systemic lupus erythematosus.

This patient most likely has acute pericarditis due to systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).  Pericarditis is the most common cardiac manifestation of SLE and usually occurs in the presence of other manifestations of active disease (eg, joint pain, fatigue, malar rash, anemia, thrombocytopenia).

Patients with pericarditis typically have pleuritic chest pain that can radiate posteriorly to the bilateral trapezius ridges (lower aspect of the bilateral scapulae).  Fever may also be present.  Auscultation at the left sternal border typically indicates a triphasic pericardial friction rub (heard in atrial systole, ventricular systole, and early ventricular diastole).  Serum troponin levels may be slightly elevated but are often undetectable.  Initial ECG typically shows subtle (diffuse) PR depression and diffuse ST elevation that eventually evolves to diffuse T wave inversion.  Associated pericardial effusions are often observed on echocardiogram but are typically small in SLE-induced pericarditis.

First-line treatment of pericarditis due to SLE is with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) (eg, ibuprofen); colchicine is rarely used.  Corticosteroids (eg, prednisone) are appropriate initial treatment in patients with a contraindication to NSAIDs (eg, renal insufficiency), and, in addition, are often effective in patients who do not respond to NSAIDs.

(Choice B)  Cervical arthritis can cause neck pain with radiation to the shoulders.  However, a pericardial friction rub makes pericarditis the most likely cause of this patient's pain.

(Choice C)  Costochondritis describes inflammation of the parasternal cartilage.  Patients typically present with chest discomfort that is worse with movement and reproducible with chest palpation.

(Choice D)  Patients with SLE often develop premature coronary artery disease in the fourth or fifth decade of life.  However, myocardial ischemia would be quite rare in this young patient, even in the setting of underlying SLE.

(Choice E)  Pulmonary embolism typically presents with sudden onset of dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, and hypoxemia.  Patients with SLE are at increased risk, but a pericardial friction rub is not typical.

(Choice F)  Verrucous (Libman-Sacks) endocarditis is characterized by the deposition of sterile vegetation (eg, immune complexes, thrombus) on cardiac valves; it can occur in patients with advanced malignancy or SLE.  Patients are usually asymptomatic but may have symptoms of systemic embolization (eg, focal weakness due to stroke).

Educational objective:
Pericarditis is the most common cardiac manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).  Patients typically have pleuritic chest pain, a pericardial friction rub, and diffuse ECG changes accompanied by other manifestations of active SLE (eg, joint pain, cytopenia).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Acute pericarditis

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Cardiac manifestations of systemic lupus erythematosus.
Cardiac involvement in systemic lupus erythematosus.

questionList.questionText: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the office for a routine presports physical evaluation.  The patient has no symptoms.  He plays competitive soccer for his high school.  Blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, pulse is 62/min, and respirations are 15/min.  BMI is 27 kg/m2.  The patient is well built with increased skeletal muscle mass.  Physical examination is unremarkable.  ECG demonstrates normal sinus rhythm with T-wave inversion in leads V5 and V6.  Echocardiography reveals left ventricular hypertrophy with impaired early diastolic filling and mild left atrial enlargement.  What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Distinguishing hypertrophic cardiomyopathy from athlete's heart

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

Athlete's heart

Family history

Common

Usually unremarkable

ECG findings

LVH criteria + depolarization &/or repolarization abnormalities*

LVH criteria without other abnormalities

Left atrial size

Enlarged

Normal

LV cavity size

Usually decreased

Slightly enlarged

LV wall thickness

≥15 mm

<15 mm

Focal septal
hypertrophy

Yes

No

LV diastolic
function

Impaired

Normal

*Common depolarization abnormalities include prominent Q waves; common repolarization abnormalities include T-wave inversions.

LV = left ventricular; LVH = left ventricular hypertrophy.

This patient with ECG showing repolarization abnormalities (ie, lateral T-wave inversions) and echocardiography revealing diastolic dysfunction and left atrial enlargement most likely has hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM).  HCM is an autosomal dominant inherited condition involving mutations in genes that encode proteins of the cardiac sarcomere.  The phenotypic manifestations typically begin during adolescence and include the following:

  • Asymmetric left ventricular (LV) hypertrophy, usually primarily affecting the interventricular septum
  • Myocardial disarray
  • Coronary microvascular dysfunction with a poorly developed capillary network

Depending on the degree of interventricular septal hypertrophy, many patients with HCM have dynamic LV outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction that can be recognized by a crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the left sternal border.  The LVOT obstruction commonly causes exertional symptoms (eg, dyspnea, lightheadedness).  However, not all patients have significant LVOT obstruction and the associated murmur.  Such patients may be asymptomatic or may still have exertional symptoms (eg, dyspnea, angina) caused by myocardial oxygen supply-demand mismatch.  These patients may also still be at increased risk for ventricular tachycardia and sudden cardiac death.

(Choice A)  Athlete's heart consists of physiologic adaptations that occur in response to intense exercise training.  Left ventricular hypertrophy is typically present, but impaired diastolic filling and left atrial enlargement are not expected and suggest HCM.  Significant depolarization or repolarization abnormalities on ECG are also not expected (sinus bradycardia, increased QRS voltage, and J point elevation may be seen).

(Choice B)  Brugada syndrome follows autosomal dominant inheritance and usually involves mutations affecting cardiac sodium channels.  Affected patients have ECG abnormalities (eg, ST elevation in leads V1 and V2) and are at increased risk of sudden cardiac death (due to ventricular arrhythmia), but no structural cardiac abnormalities are typically present.

(Choice D)  Prolonged, uncontrolled hypertension (usually for ≥10 years) is the most common cause of LV hypertrophy.  This concentric LV hypertrophy commonly leads to impaired diastolic function and left atrial enlargement, but it is highly unlikely in this adolescent patient who currently has normal blood pressure.

Educational objective:
Patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) may not have significant left ventricular outflow tract obstruction to cause a murmur.  Findings that differentiate HCM from athlete's heart, another potential cause of left ventricular hypertrophy in young patients, include depolarization or repolarization abnormalities on ECG and evidence of diastolic dysfunction or left atrial enlargement on echocardiography.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Long-term outcome of nonobstructive versus obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

questionList.questionText: A 50-year-old woman comes to the office for follow-up.  At her last visit 3 months ago, the patient was diagnosed with primary hypertension and amlodipine was prescribed.  She has had no chest pain, dyspnea, headaches, or constipation but has noted mild lower extremity edema over the past 6 weeks.  She has no other medical conditions and takes no other medications.  She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs.  The patient has no known drug allergies.  Blood pressure is 146/84 mm Hg and pulse is 76/min.  Physical examination shows symmetric 1+ pitting edema of the bilateral lower extremities without skin changes or varicosities.  The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient recently started taking amlodipine and has developed peripheral edema, a common adverse effect of dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (eg, amlodipine, nifedipine).  It likely results from preferential vasodilation of peripheral arterioles (in comparison with peripheral venules), causing increased capillary hydrostatic pressure and extravasation of fluid into the interstitium.

ACE inhibitors (eg, lisinopril) and angiotensin II receptor blockers (eg, losartan) induce balanced arteriolar and venular vasodilation via inhibition of angiotensin II, and have been shown to reduce calcium channel blocker–induced peripheral edema.  This is likely because the peripheral venodilation helps normalize capillary hydrostatic pressure.  Therefore, the addition of lisinopril to this patient's amlodipine is the best next step in management as it should help reduce her persistently elevated blood pressure and minimize her peripheral edema.

(Choice A)  Because calcium channel blocker–induced peripheral edema is due to displacement of intravascular fluid volume rather than an increase in total fluid volume, diuretics (eg, furosemide) are not a recommended treatment as they typically lead to dehydration.

(Choice C)  Increasing the amlodipine dose would help control this patient's persistently elevated blood pressure, but it is not appropriate as it would likely worsen her peripheral edema.

(Choice D)  Urine protein measurement can be used to evaluate for nephrotic syndrome, which can present with peripheral edema.  However, the peripheral edema is usually accompanied by more generalized anasarca (eg, facial edema), which is absent in this patient.  In addition, the onset of a common adverse effect several weeks after initiation of amlodipine is most consistent with calcium channel blocker–induced peripheral edema.

(Choice E)  Echocardiography can be used to evaluate for heart failure.  However, heart failure is less likely in this patient in the absence of dyspnea and in the setting of a normal physical examination other than peripheral edema (ie, no jugular venous distension or lung crackles).

Educational objective:
Peripheral edema is a common adverse effect of dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (eg, amlodipine, nifedipine), likely resulting from preferential vasodilation of peripheral arterioles that causes increased capillary hydrostatic pressure.  The addition of an ACE inhibitor (eg, lisinopril) or angiotensin II receptor blocker (eg, losartan) can minimize this adverse effect, likely via peripheral venodilation to help normalize capillary hydrostatic pressure.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Calcium channel blocker

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Effect of renin-angiotensin system blockade on calcium channel blocker–associated peripheral edema.

questionList.questionText:
A 64-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to sharp, left-sided chest pain for the past 24 hours.  The pain is worsened by deep breathing and relieved with leaning forward.  He also reports decreased appetite, fatigue, and occasional nausea over the past several weeks.  The patient had an acute non–ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction 2 years ago wherein a stent was placed in the right coronary artery.  Medical conditions include type 2 diabetes mellitus complicated by retinopathy and peripheral neuropathy, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hypothyroidism, and chronic kidney disease.  Temperature is 36.1 C (97 F), blood pressure is 142/86 mm Hg, pulse is 98/min, and respirations are 16/min.  A friction rub is heard at the left lower sternal border.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Hemoglobin9.0 g/dL
Leukocytes7,800/mm3
Potassium5.4 mEq/L
Bicarbonate17 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen96 mg/dL
Creatinine5.5 mg/dL
Troponin I0.012 (normal: <0.012)

ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with asymmetric T-wave inversion in leads V5 and V6.  Echocardiography reveals a small pericardial effusion but is otherwise normal.  What is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Acute pericarditis

Etiology

  • Viral or idiopathic
  • Autoimmune disease (eg, SLE)
  • Uremia (acute or chronic kidney failure)
  • Post myocardial infarction
    • Early: peri-infarction pericarditis
    • Late: Dressler syndrome

Clinical features & diagnosis

  • Pleuritic chest pain (↓ when sitting) ± fever
  • Pericardial friction rub (highly specific)
  • ECG: diffuse ST-segment elevation & PR-segment depression
  • Echocardiography: pericardial effusion

Treatment

  • NSAIDs & colchicine for viral or idiopathic etiology
  • Variable for other etiologies

NSAID = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug; SLE = systemic lupus erythematosus.

This patient's sharp, pleuritic chest pain, pericardial friction rub, and pericardial effusion are consistent with acute pericarditis.  His chronic kidney disease (CKD) and markedly elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) concentration suggest uremia as the likely etiology.  Late post-myocardial infarction pericarditis (ie, Dressler syndrome) is also a possibility but less likely in that it is rare and usually manifests within weeks or several months of myocardial infarction.

Uremic pericarditis can occur in patients with acute or chronic renal failure and BUN >60 mg/dL, though the onset is variable and many patients will not develop pericarditis even with BUN >100 mg/dL.  The presentation is similar to other etiologies of acute pericarditis; however, the classic ECG findings of diffuse ST-segment elevation and PR-segment depression are typically absent because the inflammation from uremic pericarditis does not involve the myocardium.

Uremic pericarditis is a strong indication for the initiation of dialysis as the pericarditis is unlikely to resolve without a reduction in uremia.  Inadequately treated uremic pericarditis poses the risk of progressive pericardial fluid accumulation and cardiac tamponade.

(Choices A and B)  Colchicine in combination with a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) (eg, indomethacin, high-dose aspirin) is the treatment of choice for most etiologies of acute pericarditis (eg, viral, idiopathic); prednisone is often substituted for an NSAID in patients with a contraindication (eg, renal insufficiency).  This treatment is sometimes used as an adjunct therapy for uremic pericarditis but is generally ineffective on its own as dialysis is needed to decrease the uremia.  Anticoagulation is contraindicated in uremic pericarditis due to elevated bleeding risk (eg, uremia-induced platelet dysfunction) and concern for bleeding into the pericardial space.

(Choice D)  Pericardiocentesis is used for treatment of cardiac tamponade; however, tamponade is uncommon with a small pericardial effusion and is ruled out by this patient's high blood pressure.

(Choice E)  Stress echocardiography is occasionally useful in the evaluation of acute coronary syndrome (eg, an uncertain diagnosis of unstable angina), but pleuritic chest pain that improves upon sitting up is not consistent with acute coronary syndrome.  Mild troponin elevations are common in patients with CKD (ie, baseline troponin is chronically elevated).

Educational objective:
Uremic pericarditis can occur in patients with blood urea nitrogen levels >60 mg/dL.  It presents like other etiologies of acute pericarditis except that classic ECG findings (ie, diffuse ST-segment elevation and PR-segment depression) are typically absent.  Dialysis is the best treatment.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Chronic kidney disease

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Pericardial involvement in end-stage renal disease.

questionList.questionText:
A 47-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to chest pain.  He says the pain is sharp and substernal, and it began this morning.  Swallowing and deep breathing make the pain worse.  The patient reports that 3 days ago he had a sore throat and muscle pains, but these symptoms are currently resolved.  His medical history is otherwise unremarkable.  The patient does not smoke or consume alcohol.  He has no significant history of cardiac disease in his family.  Temperature is 37.9 C (100.2 F), blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, pulse is 98/min, and respirations are 20/min.  There is no tenderness with palpation of the chest wall.  During cardiac auscultation, a scratchy sound is heard at the left sternal border just before S1, again between S1 and S2, and then faintly just after S2.  The lungs are clear on auscultation.  ECG reveals a sinus rhythm with PR segment depression in both precordial and limb leads.  Laboratory values are as follows:

Leukocytes9,000/mm3
Creatinine0.9 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Acute pericarditis

Etiology

  • Viral or idiopathic
  • Autoimmune disease (eg, SLE)
  • Uremia (acute or chronic kidney failure)
  • Post myocardial infarction
    • Early: peri-infarction pericarditis
    • Late: Dressler syndrome

Clinical features & diagnosis

  • Pleuritic chest pain (↓ when sitting) ± fever
  • Pericardial friction rub (highly specific)
  • ECG: diffuse ST-segment elevation & PR-segment depression
  • Echocardiography: pericardial effusion

Treatment

  • NSAIDs & colchicine for viral or idiopathic etiology
  • Variable for other etiologies

NSAID = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug; SLE = systemic lupus erythematosus.

This patient most likely has acute viral pericarditis.  Most cases of acute pericarditis are thought to be due to viral infection, and many viruses have been implicated (eg, adenovirus, coxsackievirus, echovirus, influenza virus, HIV).  Patients typically have sharp chest pain that is worse with deep breathing (pleuritic) or swallowing and may follow several days of a viral prodrome (eg, fatigue, sore throat, myalgias).  Auscultation at the left sternal border usually indicates a pericardial friction rub (high-frequency grating or scratching sound) that is often triphasic (occurring during atrial systole, ventricular systole, and early ventricular diastole).  ECG characteristically shows diffuse PR depression (due to inflammation of atrial myocardium) and diffuse ST elevation (due to inflammation of ventricular myocardium), but findings can vary.  Pericardial effusion is present in >50% of cases.

Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) (eg, ibuprofen, indomethacin) in combination with colchicine are the preferred treatment for patients with viral (or idiopathic) pericarditis.  Colchicine decreases the rate of recurrent pericarditis in these patients.

(Choices A and H)  Acute pericarditis is an inflammatory process.  Analgesics such as acetaminophen and narcotics (eg, oxycodone) do not have anti-inflammatory properties and therefore do not play a role in management.

(Choice B)  Bacterial organisms (eg, staphylococcus, pneumococcus) are rare causes of acute purulent pericarditis, and tuberculosis may cause subacute or chronic pericarditis.  This patient's presentation with a viral prodrome is consistent with viral pericarditis, for which antibiotics (eg, azithromycin) do not play a role.

(Choices C and G)  Heparin and nitroglycerin are indicated in patients with acute coronary syndrome, which typically presents with nonpleuritic (rather than pleuritic) chest pain.

(Choice E)  High-dose (rather than low-dose) aspirin is sometimes used in combination with colchicine in treating acute pericarditis.  However, aspirin monotherapy is rarely used.

(Choices F and I)  Corticosteroids (eg, prednisone) are used in patients with a contraindication to NSAIDs (eg, renal insufficiency) or failure of combination NSAID/colchicine therapy.  They are not used as initial therapy or in combination with NSAIDs (eg, naproxen) in patients with viral pericarditis.

Educational objective:
Patients with acute viral (or idiopathic) pericarditis should be initially treated with a combination of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (eg, ibuprofen) and colchicine, as colchicine lowers the rate of recurrent pericarditis.  Corticosteroids (eg, prednisone) are second-line therapy for these patients.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Acute pericarditis

questionMappingReferencesList.title: International collaborative systematic review of controlled clinical trials on pharmacologic treatments for acute pericarditis and its recurrences.

questionList.questionText: A 27-year-old woman comes to the office due to intermittent episodes of palpitations and dyspnea on exertion.  Blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg and pulse is 78/min.  On examination, there is no peripheral edema or jugular venous distension.  The lungs are clear to auscultation.  A 3/6 ejection-type systolic murmur is heard along the left sternal border and decreases in intensity when the patient moves from a standing to a squatting position.  Which of the following additional history is most helpful for establishing a diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Effect of maneuvers on hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

Physiologic effect

Left ventricular blood volume

Murmur intensity

Valsalva (strain phase)

↓ Preload

↓

↑

Abrupt standing

Nitroglycerin administration

Sustained hand grip

↑ Afterload

↑

↓

Squatting

↑ Afterload & preload

Passive leg raise

↑ Preload

This patient with palpitations, dyspnea, and a 3/6 systolic murmur that decreases in intensity with maneuvers that increase left ventricular blood volume (eg, squatting) most likely has hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM).  HCM typically involves enlargement of the interventricular septum, which can cause dynamic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction that leads to exertional symptoms (eg, dyspnea, angina, light-headedness, syncope).

HCM is the most common inherited cardiomyopathy in the United States.  It is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion, with roughly half of cases resulting from an identifiable mutation in genes encoding for myocardial contractile proteins of the cardiac sarcomere.  Cardiac myosin-binding protein C and cardiac beta-myosin heavy chain are most commonly affected, accounting for approximately 40% and 30% of identifiable mutations, respectively.  The phenotypic manifestations of the disease (eg, septal enlargement) typically develop around the time of adolescence.  Affected patients often have a recognizable family history of HCM but not always because sporadic mutations can occur, not all mutations responsible for the HCM phenotype have been identified, and the phenotypic penetrance of known mutations is not complete (ie, not all patients with an identifiable gene mutation demonstrate the HCM phenotype).

(Choices B, C, D, and E)  Chronic use of injectable sympathomimetics (eg, amphetamines, cocaine), receipt of anthracycline chemotherapy (eg, doxorubicin), occupational exposure to cobalt, and infection with Trypanosoma cruzi (ie, Chagas disease, which is endemic to Latin America) can all lead to dilated cardiomyopathy, but are not risk factors for HCM.  Dilated cardiomyopathy often causes secondary mitral regurgitation, recognized by a holosystolic murmur at the cardiac apex that increases, rather than decreases, in intensity with maneuvers that increase left ventricular blood volume (eg, squatting).

Educational objective:
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is an autosomal dominant inherited disorder caused by mutations in genes encoding for myocardial contractile proteins of the cardiac sarcomere.  Mutations affecting cardiac myosin-binding protein C gene or cardiac beta-myosin heavy chain gene are responsible for approximately 70% of identifiable mutations in patients with HCM.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Genetics of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy after 20 years: clinical perspectives.

questionList.questionText:
A 56-year-old man comes to the office due to progressively worsening dyspnea that began 3 months ago.  At first the dyspnea was exertional, but now the patient is breathless even at rest.  He has not had chest pain, palpitations, syncope, or ankle swelling.  The patient has no significant medical history, and he takes no medications.  He has a 30-pack-year smoking history and has been drinking alcohol heavily for the past 15 years.  There is no family history of heart disease.  Temperature is 37.1 C (98.8 F), blood pressure is 113/76 mm Hg, and pulse is 86/min.  An S3 is heard on heart auscultation; there are no murmurs.  Chest auscultation reveals bibasilar crackles.  The abdomen is soft with no evidence of ascites.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
Hematocrit32%
Mean corpuscular volume101 µm3
Platelets120,000/mm3
Leukocytes6,000/mm3
Liver function studies
Alkaline phosphatase44 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT)180 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT)66 U/L

Chest x-ray reveals an enlarged cardiac silhouette and signs of pulmonary venous congestion.  Echocardiography shows a dilated left ventricle with an estimated left ventricular ejection fraction of 25%.  Coronary angiography reveals no evidence of obstructive coronary artery disease.  Which of the following measures is most likely to reverse this patient's left ventricular dysfunction?
questionList.explanationText:
Alcohol-induced cardiomyopathy

Pathophysiology

  • Direct toxicity of ethanol leads to contractile dysfunction
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy eventually develops

Clinical presentation

  • History of heavy & prolonged alcohol use
  • Symptomatic HFrEF (eg, dyspnea, volume overload)
  • Laboratory evidence of heavy alcohol use (eg, AST/ALT >2:1)

Diagnosis

  • Consistent clinical presentation
  • Exclusion of other causes of HFrEF (eg, ischemic heart disease)

Management

  • Complete alcohol abstinence (may reverse cardiomyopathy)
  • Standard treatment of persistent HFrEF (eg, ARNI, diuretic)

ALT = alanine aminotransferase; ARNI = angiotensin receptor blocker-neprilysin inhibitor; AST = aspartate aminotransferase; HFrEF = heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.

This patient's dyspnea, bibasilar crackles, S3, and reduced left ventricular (LV) ejection fraction are consistent with decompensated heart failure.  Given his heavy alcohol use and the lack of obstructive coronary artery disease on angiography, the most likely etiology is alcohol-induced cardiomyopathy (AIC).

AIC likely involves direct toxicity of ethanol and its metabolites (eg, acetaldehyde) on myocardial mitochondria, resulting in contractile dysfunction.  Eventual compensatory eccentric hypertrophy leads to LV cavity dilation (ie, dilated cardiomyopathy).  AIC is seen almost exclusively with heavy and prolonged alcohol use (eg, >80 g [8 beers] per day for >5 years).  Patients typically have heart failure manifestations and laboratory evidence of heavy alcohol use (eg, macrocytic anemia [mean corpuscular volume >100 µm3], thrombocytopenia, AST/ALT ratio >2:1).

The diagnosis is made via a consistent clinical presentation and exclusion of other causes of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) (eg, coronary angiography to rule out ischemic heart disease, which can also cause LV dilation and dysfunction).  Optimal treatment is complete abstinence from alcohol.  If implemented early enough in the disease course, it can lead to marked improvement (and sometimes complete reversal) of LV dysfunction, with a substantial improvement in prognosis.

(Choices B, C, and D)  Tobacco smoking accelerates atherosclerosis and is a strong risk factor for ischemic heart disease; cessation should be recommended in all patients and may slightly improve LV function.  ACE inhibitors (eg, lisinopril) have been shown to reduce cardiac remodeling in patients with HFrEF, particularly following myocardial infarction.  Digoxin increases cardiac contractility and may minimally improve LV dysfunction in patients with HFrEF.  However, the positive effect of alcohol abstinence on LV function in patients with AIC is much more prominent than any of these interventions.

(Choice E)  Glucocorticoids (eg, prednisolone) may improve outcomes in some patients with severe alcohol-induced hepatitis, but these drugs have not shown benefit in AIC.

(Choice F)  Appropriate regulation of salt intake is important to help avoid volume overload in patients with HFrEF, but it does not have a significant effect on the degree of underlying LV dysfunction.

(Choice G)  Niacin deficiency can occur with heavy alcohol use, but supplementation has not been shown to improve AIC.

Educational objective:
Alcohol-induced cardiomyopathy, a type of dilated cardiomyopathy, is a potential cause of decompensated heart failure in patients with heavy and prolonged alcohol use.  Complete abstinence from alcohol is the optimal treatment as it can markedly improve left ventricular dysfunction.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Dilated cardiomyopathy

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Natural history and prognostic factors in alcoholic cardiomyopathy.

questionList.questionText: A 32-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to progressively worsening dyspnea a month after returning from a vacation in Texas.  The symptoms started with shortness of breath on exertion and have progressed to the point that she now wakes during the night with a choking sensation that improves only with sitting up.  The patient has had an active lifestyle for years but is now markedly limited in her activities.  She has no associated chest pain, skin rash, or joint pain.  Medical history is unremarkable.  Family history is significant for thyroid cancer in her aunt and lung cancer in her father.  There is no family history of coronary artery disease, heart failure, or sudden cardiac death.  The patient does not use recreational drugs.  Temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 96/min, and respirations are 14/min.  Bilateral pitting ankle edema is present.  Decreased breath sounds are noted at the bases bilaterally.  An S3 is heard on cardiac examination.  Chest x-ray reveals an enlarged cardiac silhouette and small bilateral pleural effusions.  ECG demonstrates nonspecific ST-segment changes.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
Viral myocarditis

Clinical presentation

  • Commonly asymptomatic & resolves without detection
  • Heart failure that may progress to DCM*
  • Chest pain, ventricular arrhythmia with risk of SCD
  •  Relatively young adults usually affected (eg, age <55)
  • ± Viral prodrome (eg, fever, malaise, myalgia)

Diagnosis

  • ECG: nonspecific findings
  • Laboratory: mild to moderate serum troponin elevation
  • Echocardiography: 4-chamber dilation with diffuse hypokinesis
  • Cardiac MRI: epicardial or midwall enhancement
  • Biopsy: lymphocytic infiltration, viral DNA or RNA**

Treatment

  • Supportive care to allow time for recovery
  • HFrEF medications (eg, diuretic, ACE inhibitor, beta blocker)
  • Temporary ventricular assist device, if needed
  • Heart transplant if no recovery

*Most common symptomatic presentation.

**Endomyocardial biopsy is rarely required for diagnosis.

DCM = dilated cardiomyopathy; HFrEF = heart failure with reduced ejection fraction; SCD = sudden cardiac death.

This patient's dyspnea, orthopnea, pulmonary edema, lower extremity swelling, and S3 are consistent with decompensated heart failure, which is most likely due to myocarditis.  Viral infection is the most common cause of myocarditis, and a number of viruses have been implicated, including coxsackievirus, parvovirus B19, human herpesvirus 6, adenovirus, influenza virus, HIV, and COVID-19.  An inadequate initial immune response may allow virus to invade cardiomyocytes and cause contractile dysfunction.

Viral myocarditis is commonly asymptomatic and resolves without being clinically detected.  Heart failure is the most common symptomatic presentation; decreased systolic function with ventricular dilation (eccentric hypertrophy) develops and may progress to dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM).  Less commonly, patients have chest pain that can mimic myocardial infarction.  Sudden cardiac death can occasionally occur due to ventricular arrhythmia.  Some patients describe a viral prodrome (eg, fever, malaise, myalgia) that precedes the development of cardiac symptoms, but many have no such history.

ECG in viral myocarditis typically shows nonspecific ST-segment changes.  In the setting of heart failure, echocardiogram typically shows 4-chamber dilation with diffuse wall hypokinesis.  Endomyocardial biopsy with viral PCR testing is the diagnostic gold standard but is often deferred in favor of noninvasive cardiac MRI.

(Choice A)  Coronary atherosclerosis is a common cause of heart failure (ie, ischemic heart disease) in relatively older patients (eg, age >50).  It is unlikely in this young woman with no significant risk factors for coronary artery disease (eg, family history, hypertension).

(Choice B)  Coccidioidomycosis typically manifests with symptoms similar to community-acquired pneumonia (eg, fatigue, cough, fever).  It is endemic in the southwestern United States, including parts of Texas; however, presentation with myocarditis and heart failure is very rare.

(Choice C)  Connective tissue disorders (eg, systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis) are a rare cause of myocarditis and DCM.  Absence of skin rash and joint pain makes an underlying connective tissue disorder unlikely.

(Choice D)  Severe hypothyroidism can occasionally cause heart failure and DCM but is less likely than viral myocarditis in the absence of associated signs and symptoms of hypothyroidism (eg, cold intolerance, constipation, dry skin).

(Choice E)  Lyme disease with cardiac involvement (Lyme carditis) usually presents with conduction abnormalities (eg, atrioventricular block), and DCM would be an uncommon manifestation.  Absence of conduction abnormality on ECG makes Lyme carditis less likely.

Educational objective:
Viral infection is the most common cause of myocarditis.  Viral myocarditis is a potential cause of decompensated heart failure and dilated cardiomyopathy in relatively young adults.

The diagnosis and evaluation of dilated cardiomyopathy.

questionList.questionText: A 24-year-old woman comes to the office due to dyspnea on exertion and fatigue for 2 months.  The patient felt lightheaded and almost passed out while running on a treadmill recently.  She had an upper respiratory infection 3 months ago that resolved in 3-4 days.  The patient takes no medications.  Temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 126/76 mm Hg, pulse is 76/min, and respirations are 14/min.  Oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.  Physical examination shows no apparent distress.  Jugular venous pressure is normal.  The lungs are clear to auscultation.  A crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur is heard along the left sternal border without radiation to the neck.  Rapid upstrokes of the peripheral pulses are present.  Chest x-ray is normal.  What is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
Physical examination features of LVOT obstruction due to aortic stenosis & hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

Aortic stenosis

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

Decreased preload*
(eg, Valsalva strain phase)

↓ Murmur intensity

↑ Murmur intensity

Increased afterload
(eg, handgrip)

↓ Murmur intensity

↓ Murmur intensity

S4

Often present

Often present

Ejection click*

Often present

Absent

Carotid pulses*

Soft & delayed

Brisk & often bifid

*Distinguishing feature.

LVOT = left ventricular outflow tract.

This patient with a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border and brisk carotid pulses most likely has hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM).  Many patients with HCM have asymmetric hypertrophy of the interventricular septum, which can cause dynamic left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction that leads to exertional symptoms (eg, dyspnea, lightheadedness [presyncope]).  Characteristic physical examination findings include:

  • Crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur that increases in intensity with decreased LV blood volume (and vice versa)

  • Audible S4 caused by impaired diastolic function of the thickened left ventricle

  • Brisk carotid pulses resulting from rapid and unobstructed blood ejection during early systole, followed by collapse of the LVOT by mid-to-late systole

Several of these findings are similar to those of aortic stenosis (AS), a common complication of a congenitally bicuspid aortic valve (Choice A).  With both AS and HCM, an S4 can be seen, and the crescendo-decrescendo murmur decreases in intensity with increased afterload (in HCM this is due to increased LV blood volume; in AS it is due to decreased pressure gradient across the valve).  However, HCM and AS can be differentiated by the following physical examination features:

  • Murmur characteristics: Variation in murmur intensity with decreased LV preload (decreased with AS vs increased with HCM) and location of optimal auscultation (right upper sternal border for AS vs left sternal border for HCM)

  • Ejection click: usually present with AS vs not seen with HCM

  • Carotid and peripheral pulses: soft and delayed in AS (due to obstruction of LVOT blood flow throughout systole) vs brisk and rapid in HCM

Age is also helpful as HCM usually presents in adolescents and young adults whereas AS is rare in patients age <40.  In this patient, age, murmur location, and peripheral pulse characteristics (rapid upstroke) all make HCM more likely than AS.

(Choice B)  LV systolic failure (ie, decreased contractility) can cause dyspnea and fatigue (and rarely syncope or presyncope), and may occur following viral infection (eg, dilated cardiomyopathy).  A murmur of secondary mitral regurgitation may be present but is holosystolic and best heard at the cardiac apex.  Symptomatic patients usually have evidence of volume overload with pulmonary edema and jugular venous distension.

(Choice D)  Intracardiac right-to-left shunting can occur through either an atrial or ventricular septal defect and leads to Eisenmenger syndrome.  Dyspnea is common, and syncope or presyncope can occur, but marked hypoxemia (eg, oxygen saturation <88%) is expected.

(Choice E)  Pulmonary outflow tract obstruction (eg, pulmonic stenosis) can cause dyspnea and syncope or presyncope.  It is recognized by a crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the left upper sternal border; no effect on the pulse upstroke in the systemic circulation is expected.

Educational objective:
Characteristic physical examination findings in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy include a crescendo-decrescendo murmur that increases in intensity with decreased left ventricular blood volume (and vice versa), an audible S4, and brisk carotid pulses.

questionList.questionText: A 32-year-old woman comes to the office because of fatigue, progressively worsening shortness of breath, and swelling of her feet.  The patient has had these symptoms for the last 4 or 5 days.  She denies chest pain.  The patient has no other medical conditions except for a cold 2 weeks ago.  She takes no medications.  Temperature is 36.7 C (98 F), blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 20/min.  Physical examination shows bilateral basilar crackles, elevated jugular venous pressure, and 2+ bilateral pitting edema extending above the ankles.  Complete blood count reveals no abnormalities.  Which of the following will most likely be shown on echocardiography?
questionList.explanationText:
Viral myocarditis

Clinical presentation

  • Commonly asymptomatic & resolves without detection
  • Heart failure that may progress to DCM*
  • Chest pain, ventricular arrhythmia with risk of SCD
  •  Relatively young adults usually affected (eg, age <55)
  • ± Viral prodrome (eg, fever, malaise, myalgia)

Diagnosis

  • ECG: nonspecific findings
  • Laboratory: mild to moderate serum troponin elevation
  • Echocardiography: 4-chamber dilation with diffuse hypokinesis
  • Cardiac MRI: epicardial or midwall enhancement
  • Biopsy: lymphocytic infiltration, viral DNA or RNA**

Treatment

  • Supportive care to allow time for recovery
  • HFrEF medications (eg, diuretic, ACE inhibitor, beta blocker)
  • Temporary ventricular assist device, if needed
  • Heart transplant if no recovery

*Most common symptomatic presentation.

**Endomyocardial biopsy is rarely required for diagnosis.

DCM = dilated cardiomyopathy; HFrEF = heart failure with reduced ejection fraction; SCD = sudden cardiac death.

This patient has evidence of decompensated heart failure (DHF) that is most likely due to viral myocarditis.  This condition most commonly affects relatively young adults and is often preceded by a viral prodrome (eg, upper respiratory symptoms, enteritis).

Most cases of viral myocarditis likely remain clinically undetectable, but some individuals may have a genetic predisposition that allows viral infection (eg, coxsackievirus, adenovirus, parvovirus B19) to persist within cardiomyocytes, causing disruption of myocardial contractility.  With progressive biventricular contractile failure, there is compensatory eccentric hypertrophy and the eventual development of dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM).  On echocardiography, DCM is recognized by dilated ventricular chambers and diffuse hypokinesis of the ventricular walls.

Treatment of DCM due to viral myocarditis is mostly supportive and involves medical management of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (eg, diuretics, beta blocker, ACE inhibitor), with some patients experiencing eventual recovery of cardiac function.

(Choice A)  Bacterial endocarditis of the aortic valve can cause aortic regurgitation leading to DHF; however, fever and leukocytosis are expected.

(Choice B)  Asymmetric septal hypertrophy characterizes hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), which is unlikely to present with DHF.  HCM often presents with sudden cardiac death in patients without prior symptoms.

(Choice C)  Concentric left ventricular hypertrophy results from chronic pressure overload, as can occur with systemic hypertension or severe aortic stenosis.

(Choice E)  Mitral stenosis is typically recognized by a middiastolic murmur and opening snap.  Patients can develop DHF, but mitral stenosis is unlikely in this patient with no known history of rheumatic fever.

(Choice F)  Segmental inferior wall hypokinesis is typical of inferior wall myocardial infarction (MI), which is unlikely in the absence of chest pain.  In addition, inferior wall MI often predominantly affects the right ventricle and would not cause pulmonary edema.

(Choice G)  A thickened pericardium with a loculated pericardial effusion can occur with bacterial pericarditis, often as a complication of untreated bacterial pneumonia.  Affected patients typically are acutely ill with high fever, tachycardia, and chest pain.

Educational objective:
Viral myocarditis is a potential cause of dilated cardiomyopathy in relatively young adults (eg, age <55).  Patients usually present with decompensated heart failure that is often preceded by a viral prodrome.  Echocardiography typically shows biventricular enlargement with diffuse ventricular wall hypokinesis.

questionList.questionText:
A 50-year-old man comes to the office to discuss heart disease prevention.  The patient has a history of mild abnormality in liver function tests that he says he was told is "nothing to worry about"; he has no other significant medical history.  Five years ago, the patient underwent repair of his anterior cruciate ligament.  He drinks 1 or 2 beers on most nights and has smoked a half pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years.  His father had a myocardial infarction at age 62.  The patient eats a lot of fast food because of limited time during the workday.  Prior to his knee injury, he played in a recreational soccer league and has not exercised regularly since.  The patient sits for most of the day at his job.  Temperature is 36.7 C (98.1 F) and blood pressure is 138/86 mm Hg.  Weight is 91.6 kg (201.9 lb) and height is 175.3 cm (5 ft 9 in).  BMI is 29.8 kg/m2.  Examination shows moist mucous membranes, normal jugular venous pressure, clear lung fields, and normal S1 and S2.  The abdomen is soft and nontender.  No hepatomegaly or splenomegaly is present.  There is normal range of motion, and neurologic examination is within normal limits.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Lipid panel
    Total cholesterol225 mg/dL
    HDL48 mg/dL
    LDL139 mg/dL
    Triglycerides190 mg/dL
Serum chemistry
    Sodium144 mEq/L
    Potassium4.8 mEq/L
    Chloride109 mEq/L
    Bicarbonate26 mEq/L
    Blood urea nitrogen14 mg/dL
    Creatinine1 mg/dL
    Calcium9.5 mg/dL
    Glucose104 mg/dL
Liver function studies
    Total protein7 g/dL
    Albumin4.2 g/dL
    Total bilirubin1.7 mg/dL
    Alkaline phosphatase105 U/L
    Aspartate aminotransferase35 U/L
    Alanine aminotransferase55 U/L
Complete blood count
    Leukocytes7,500/mm3
    Hemoglobin14.4 g/dL
    Mean corpuscular volume91 fL
    Platelets215,000/mm3

Which of the following would provide the most important information in determining whether to start lipid-lowering therapy in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Indications for statin therapy in prevention of ASCVD

Secondary prevention

  • Established ASCVD
    • Acute coronary syndrome
    • Stable angina
    • Arterial revascularization (eg, CABG)
    • Stroke, TIA, PAD

Primary prevention

  • LDL ≥190 mg/dL
  • Age ≥40 with diabetes mellitus
  • Estimated 10-year risk of ASCVD >7.5%-10%

ASCVD = atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease; CABG = coronary artery bypass grafting; PAD = peripheral artery disease; TIA = transient ischemic attack.

Current guidelines recommend the use of statins (eg, atorvastatin, rosuvastatin) for secondary prevention in patients with known atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD), including history of myocardial infarction, angina, arterial revascularization, stroke/transient ischemic attack, and peripheral artery disease.  In addition, patients with serum LDL ≥190 mg/dL (suggestive of familial hypercholesterolemia) and those age ≥40 with diabetes mellitus are considered at high risk for ASCVD, and primary prevention with statin therapy is indicated.

In patients who do not meet any of the above criteria, the decision to initiate statin therapy for primary prevention of ASCVD is less straightforward; it is generally based on an estimated future risk of cardiovascular events.  Guidelines recommend using the Pooled Cohort Equations cardiovascular risk calculator, which takes into account ethnicity, age, sex, total cholesterol, HDL, diabetes status, smoking status, and blood pressure, to estimate the 10-year risk of ASCVD.  Initiation of statin therapy is recommended in patients with an estimated 10-year risk of ASCVD >7.5%-10% (guidelines vary on the specific cutoff).  A healthy lifestyle (eg, exercise, diet) should be encouraged in all patients regardless of whether statin therapy is indicated.

(Choice A)  Family history of premature ASCVD in a first-degree relative (eg, onset at age <50 in father) is associated with increased risk of cardiovascular events.  However, in part due to inaccurate reporting, it is a less useful parameter than pooled analysis of other traditional risk factors.

(Choice B)  Exercise stress testing is used to evaluate for ASCVD in patients with symptoms suggestive of the condition (eg, reproducible chest pain with exertion), but it is not typically indicated in asymptomatic patients.

(Choice C)  Elevated high-sensitivity C-reactive protein levels have been correlated with increased risk of cardiovascular events.  However, the test is nonspecific and is not preferred over pooled analysis using traditional risk factors.

(Choice D)  Some apolipoproteins (eg, apolipoprotein B-100) function as lipid structural proteins.  However, serum apolipoprotein concentrations are not routinely used to evaluate ASCVD risk.

(Choice F)  Unless the level is ≥190 mg/dL, LDL alone is not typically used to guide the initiation of statin therapy.  LDL<70 mg/dL is sometimes used as a cutoff to withhold statin therapy when it is otherwise indicated.

Educational objective:
Estimated atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk can be calculated using the Pooled Cohort Equations cardiovascular risk calculator.  Initiation of statin therapy is recommended for primary prevention in patients with a 10-year ASCVD risk >7.5%-10%.

questionList.questionText:
A 70-year-old woman comes to the office due to progressive lower extremity edema over the last 2 months.  The patient's mobility is impaired due to knee osteoarthritis, but she has recently become somewhat tired and short of breath with daily activities.  Her stomach feels full and her appetite has been decreased.  The patient has had no forgetfulness or mood conditions.  Blood pressure is 126/75 mm Hg and pulse is 70/min and regular.  Jugular veins are distended with the patient in the seated position.  There are no heart murmurs.  Breath sounds are decreased at the bases bilaterally.  The abdomen is distended with flank dullness on percussion.  There is 3+ peripheral edema.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Hemoglobin11.2 g/dL
Sodium134 mEq/L
Creatinine0.9 mg/dL

Urine albumin excretion is 1 g/24 hr.  Echocardiography reveals biatrial enlargement, marked concentric left ventricular thickening, and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 70%.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
Major types of systemic amyloidosis

Primary

Secondary

Age related

Dialysis related

Disease
association

Plasma cell dyscrasia

Chronic infection/
inflammation

Elderly men

ESRD on dialysis

Precursor
protein

↓

Misfolding
mechanism

↓

Amyloid
fibril type

Immunoglobulin
light chains

↓

Increased
production

↓

AL

Serum
amyloid A

↓

Increased
production

↓

Transthyretin
(prealbumin)

↓

Accumulation
over time

↓

ATTR*

β2-Microglobulin 
↓

↓

Aβ2M

Clinical
manifestations

Nephropathy, hepatosplenomegaly, cardiomyopathy (AL > AA), peripheral neuropathy, macroglossia, skin bruising

Cardiomyopathy, CTS, other peripheral neuropathy

Scapulohumeral arthritis, CTS

Amyloid names begin with "A" followed by the precursor protein abbreviation.

*ATTR also occurs in a hereditary form that affects younger patients.

CTS = carpal tunnel syndrome; ESRD = end-stage renal disease.

This patient's fatigue, dyspnea, and fluid retention are consistent with heart failure.  Several features suggest that, in this case, the most likely diagnosis is cardiac amyloidosis.  Amyloidosis (characterized by tissue infiltration with insoluble protein fibrils) that involves the heart is usually caused by amyloid transthyretin (ATTR) or amyloid light chain (AL).  ATTR occurs in both hereditary and age-related forms and commonly affects the nervous system (eg, carpal tunnel syndrome) in addition to the heart.  AL can affect the heart and many other organ systems (eg, kidneys, liver, skin, gastrointestinal tract, peripheral nerves) and is most likely in this patient with proteinuria and apparent early satiety (eg, abdominal fullness, decreased appetite)

Myocardial infiltration by amyloid proteins typically creates stiff and thickened ventricular walls manifesting as restrictive cardiomyopathy.  Echocardiographic evidence of concentric left ventricular hypertrophy, especially in the absence of hypertension, can be a helpful clue.  Diastolic filling of the left ventricle is impaired, causing elevated hydrostatic pressure to back up and lead to biatrial enlargement, pulmonary edema, and signs of right-sided heart failure (eg, jugular venous distension [JVD]; ascites causing abdominal distension with flank dullness; lower extremity edema).  Left ventricular (LV) ejection fraction is typically preserved or may be increased (ie, heart failure with preserved ejection fraction).  A small pericardial effusion is common, possibly resulting from an inflammatory response to infiltrating amyloid.

(Choice A)  Chronic interstitial nephritis can be caused by medications (eg, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs), infection (eg, HIV, syphilis), and autoimmune disease (eg, Sjögren syndrome).  It often causes proteinuria but would not explain this patient's ventricular wall thickening.

(Choice B)  Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) typically involves asymmetric thickening of the interventricular septum with reduced LV cavity size, and commonly demonstrates normal or increased LV ejection fraction.  Amyloidosis is more likely in this patient given the absence of the characteristic HCM systolic murmur and the presence of proteinuria and early satiety.

(Choice C)  Inferior vena cava thrombosis can lead to lower extremity edema and ascites, but JVD and evidence of pulmonary edema are not expected.

(Choice D)  Ischemic heart disease is a common cause of heart failure, but it typically leads to LV systolic dysfunction and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.

(Choice E)  Nephrotic range proteinuria (ie, >3.5 g/24 hr) can result in protein malnutrition.  Edema is common, but it tends to cause loss of cardiac muscle mass rather than thickening of the myocardium.

(Choice G)  Thiamine deficiency can lead to high-output heart failure, which demonstrates ventricular cavity enlargement on echocardiography.  Thickened ventricular walls are not expected.

Educational objective:
Cardiac amyloidosis classically manifests as restrictive cardiomyopathy and should be a diagnostic consideration in patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction.  Amyloid light chain commonly demonstrates prominent organ system involvement outside the heart (eg, nephropathy, bruising).

questionList.questionText: A 52-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after a brief episode of unresponsiveness.  The patient recalls rushing to catch a bus for work.  She began feeling sweaty and warm after sitting down, lost consciousness, and then slumped in her seat.  She regained consciousness after approximately one minute and was not confused afterward.  She has never had a similar episode and reports no chest pain or palpitations prior to the event.  Medical history includes hypertension and Sjögren syndrome.  Medications are amlodipine and artificial tears.  Family history is significant for myocardial infarction in her father.  The patient does not use tobacco and drinks alcohol on social occasions.  She regularly walks 2 blocks without difficulty as part of her commute.  When she is supine, blood pressure is 132/74 mm Hg and pulse is 72/min; on standing, blood pressure is 125/70 mm Hg and pulse is 78/min.  Physical examination shows no signs of head injury.  Cranial nerve examination is normal.  There is no focal weakness or sensory loss.  The lungs are clear on auscultation, and heart sounds are normal.  The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities.  ECG shows a normal sinus rhythm.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Clues to etiology of syncope

Reflex syncope

Vasovagal

  • Trigger (eg, emotional stress, prolonged standing)
  • Prodrome (eg, nausea, sweating, warmth)

Situational

  • Occurs with micturition, defecation, swallowing, or coughing

Carotid hypersensitivity

  • Tactile stimulation of carotid sinus while standing
  • Advanced age, carotid atherosclerosis

Orthostatic syncope

Medications

  • Vasodilators (eg, alpha-1 blockers, antihypertensives)
  • Inotropic/chronotropic blockade (eg, beta blockers)

Hypovolemia

  • History consistent with volume loss

Autonomic dysfunction

  • Advanced age
  • Predisposing disease (eg, DM, Parkinson)

Cardiac syncope

LV outflow obstruction

  • Syncope with exertion
  • Systolic ejection murmur

Ventricular tachycardia

  • No warning symptoms
  • Cardiomyopathy or ischemic HD (monomorphic)
  • QT-interval prolongation (polymorphic)

Conduction impairment*

  • Preceding fatigue or light-headedness
  • ECG abnormalities (eg, sinus pauses, dropped QRS complexes)

*Sick sinus syndrome or advanced atrioventricular block.

DM = diabetes mellitus; HD = heart disease; LV = left ventricular.

This patient's presentation is classic for vasovagal syncope, the most common type of reflex syncope.  Vasovagal syncope typically involves a brief loss of consciousness (LOC) (eg, 1-2 min) preceded by a trigger (eg, emotional stress while rushing for the bus) and a vagal prodrome (eg, diaphoresis, warmth).  Classic vasovagal syncope is usually diagnosed based on history alone, but other causes of syncope that are either more serious or require intervention must be excluded.

Cardiac syncope must be considered because it results from underlying cardiac disease that may cause sudden cardiac death.  It typically occurs without warning in patients with structural heart disease (eg, aortic stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy) or conduction disturbances (eg, long QT syndrome) and is usually suggested by systolic murmur or ECG abnormalities.  The presence of a murmur should prompt further investigation with echocardiography, and ECG abnormalities should prompt further conduction system workup (eg, 24-hr Holter monitoring).  However, patients (such as this one) with a clinical history consistent with vasovagal syncope and no findings to suggest cardiac syncope require no further cardiac workup (Choices A and C).

Orthostatic syncope should be considered because appropriate intervention (eg, fluid resuscitation, medication discontinuation) may be indicated.  This patient is at increased risk of orthostatic syncope due to a medication that impairs peripheral vasoconstriction (ie, amlodipine); however, syncope occurred while sitting, and vital signs are not consistent with orthostatic hypotension.

Given this patient's classic presentation for vasovagal syncope and low likelihood of cardiac or orthostatic syncope, she requires no further testing or intervention at this time.

(Choice B)  CT scan of the head may be indicated for LOC associated with ongoing neurologic symptoms (eg, headache) or findings (eg, focal deficits); it is not indicated in classic vasovagal syncope.

(Choice D)  Seizure activity (diagnosed on electroencephalography) can cause a sudden LOC; however, other suggestive features (eg, jerking movements of the limbs, tongue laceration, postictal period) are typically present.

(Choice F)  Tilt-table testing can help distinguish between orthostatic and vasovagal syncope if the etiology is unclear and episodes recur.  It is not indicated after a single episode classic for vasovagal syncope.

Educational objective:
Classic vasovagal syncope involves a brief loss of consciousness preceded by a trigger (eg, emotional distress) and a vagal prodrome (eg, diaphoresis, warmth).  No further workup or intervention is indicated when there are no physical examination or ECG findings to suggest other etiologies (eg, cardiac, orthostatic).

questionList.questionText:
A 4-week-old male infant with hypoplastic left heart syndrome has had difficulty feeding and an episode of vomiting over the last 24 hours.  He was born at term via normal spontaneous vaginal delivery.  The patient underwent palliative heart surgery at age 1 week; the procedure involved cardiotomy and extensive intracardiac and aortic arch repair.  His postoperative course was uncomplicated, and he has remained in the hospital for weaning of oxygen and titration of cardiac medications.  Two additional palliative surgeries are planned.  Temperature is 38.3 C (101 F), blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg, pulse is 175/min, and respirations are 70/min.  Pulse oximetry is 80% on room air.  He is cyanotic and small for his age.  Cardiopulmonary examination is notable for distant heart sounds, tachycardia, and tachypnea.  Abdominal examination is normal.  Chest radiographs from a week ago and today are shown below.

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's acute presentation?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient with recent cardiac surgery developed tachycardia, tachypnea, distant heart sounds, and enlargement of the cardiac silhouette on chest x-ray, suggestive of pericardial effusion.  A pericardial effusion occurs when inflamed pericardial cells produce increased fluid, which accumulates in the pericardial sac around the heart.  This is common a few weeks after cardiac surgery due to immune-mediated inflammatory damage to the pericardium (ie, postpericardiotomy syndrome).

Small pericardial effusions are usually asymptomatic because the pericardium stretches to accommodate the fluid.  However, larger effusions can compress the heart and impair cardiac filling.  Infants can develop decreased appetite and vomiting whereas older children may present with pericardial friction rub and pleuritic chest pain.  Fever may be present due to inflammation, and tachypnea and tachycardia occur in response to decreased cardiac output.  The effusion obscures auscultation, causing distant, "muffled" heart sounds on examination.

Fluid accumulation around the heart causes an enlarged cardiac silhouette on chest x-ray, as seen in this patient.  Costophrenic angles remain sharp unless there is an accompanying pleural effusion, and the stomach bubble is a normal finding that can be seen.  Echocardiogram confirms the diagnosis.  Patients with signs of hemodynamic compromise should undergo drainage of pericardial fluid.

(Choice A)  Congestive heart failure is a complication of congenital heart disease that can present with poor feeding and tachycardia.  However, pulmonary vascular congestion (represented in an adult patient in the exhibit) and interstitial edema would be expected on chest x-ray.

(Choice B)  Children with congenital heart disease are at increased risk for bacterial endocarditis.  Presentation includes fever and tachycardia; however, a new murmur, not distant heart sounds, would be present on examination.  Other findings consistent with endocarditis include petechiae, splinter hemorrhages, and Janeway lesions.

(Choice C)  Postoperative mediastinitis can complicate heart surgery and present with fever and tachycardia.  However, it is classically associated with sternal wound erythema and drainage; and rather than showing an enlarged cardiac silhouette, chest x-ray may show mediastinal widening, although this finding is often absent in cases of postoperative mediastinitis (compared to mediastinitis due to esophageal rupture or odontogenic/retropharyngeal infection spread).

(Choice E)  Pulmonary embolism can present with tachycardia, tachypnea, hypoxia, and right heart failure.  Chest x-ray is usually normal.  This patient's hypoxia is typical of hypoplastic left heart syndrome following the first palliative surgery and is not indicative of pulmonary embolism.

Educational objective:
Pericardial effusion can occur after cardiac surgery and typically presents with distant, "muffled" heart sounds and signs of decreased cardiac output (eg, tachycardia, tachypnea).  An enlarged cardiac silhouette on chest x-ray is characteristic.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Pericardial effusion

questionList.questionText:
A 64-year-old man comes to the office due to shortness of breath and abdominal distension.  He was treated for Hodgkin lymphoma with radiation and chemotherapy 18 years ago and was told that he was cured.  The patient drinks alcohol regularly.  Temperature is 36.7 C (98.1 F), blood pressure is 120/76 mm Hg, pulse is 92/min, and respirations are 20/min.  Neck examination shows jugular venous pulsations 9 cm above the sternal angle.  The abdomen is distended with a positive fluid wave.  The liver edge is palpated 5 cm below the right costal edge.  There is bilateral pitting edema of the lower extremities.  Initial laboratory results are as follows:

Serum creatinine0.8 mg/dL
Albumin4.0 g/dL
Total bilirubin1.0 mg/dL
PT11 sec

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Constrictive pericarditis

Etiology

  • Recurrent idiopathic or viral pericarditis
  • Cardiac surgery or radiation therapy
  • Tuberculous pericarditis (endemic areas)

Clinical presentation

  • Fatigue, dyspnea on exertion
  • Peripheral edema, ascites, hepatic congestion
  • Pericardial knock in early diastole
  • Elevated JVP with Kussmaul sign*
  • Prominent y descent of JVP waveform

Diagnostic findings

  • Chest x-ray: pericardial calcification
  • Cardiac CT scan/MRI: pericardial thickening & calcification
  • Echocardiography: biatrial enlargement, normal ventricular wall thickness & cavity size, abnormal septal motion during respiration

*Absence of the expected fall in JVP during inspiration.

JVP = jugular venous pulse.

This patient's presentation is suggestive of right-sided heart failure, most likely due to constrictive pericarditis, a potential late complication of radiation therapy.  Survivors of Hodgkin lymphoma are at increased risk for cardiac disease, which can present 10-20 years or more after mediastinal irradiation and/or anthracycline therapy.  Potential cardiac complications of Hodgkin lymphoma include acute or delayed pericardial disease, accelerated coronary atherosclerosis, restrictive cardiomyopathy, heart failure, valvular abnormalities, and conduction defects.

Constrictive pericarditis occurs as a result of scarring and subsequent loss of normal elasticity of the pericardial sac.  The inelastic pericardium restricts venous return to the right side of the heart, leading to right-sided heart failure.  Patients typically have peripheral edema, ascites (eg, positive abdominal fluid wave), and hepatic congestion with hepatomegaly, which can progress to cirrhosis (cardiac cirrhosis).  Physical examination typically shows elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP) with hepatojugular reflux, Kussmaul sign (paradoxical increase in JVP on inspiration), and a pericardial knock (early-diastolic sound).

Patients may have pericardial calcifications on chest radiograph.  Echocardiography confirms the diagnosis and typically shows increased pericardial thickness, abnormal septal motion, and biatrial enlargement.  Diuretics can provide temporary relief, but pericardiectomy is the definitive treatment for patients with refractory symptoms.

(Choices B and C)  Portal vein thrombosis or compression (eg, due to hepatocellular carcinoma) most commonly occurs in the setting of cirrhosis.  Ascites and lower extremity edema are typically present, but JVP elevation and an enlarged liver are not expected (a cirrhotic liver is usually shrunken).  In addition, cirrhosis is unlikely with a normal serum bilirubin and PT.

(Choice D)  Lymphoma recurrence could cause thoracic duct obstruction and lead to lymphatic fluid leaking into the pleural space, resulting in chylothorax.  However, thoracic duct obstruction would not explain ascites, hepatomegaly, and elevated JVP.

(Choice E)  Heavy proteinuria and resulting hypoalbuminemia can cause edema and ascites (ie, nephrotic syndrome), but this patient's serum albumin is normal.

(Choice F)  Venous valve incompetence is a common cause of lower extremity edema but would not explain this patient's other findings of right-sided heart failure.

Educational objective:
Constrictive pericarditis is a potential complication of mediastinal radiation and presents with signs and symptoms of right-sided heart failure, including peripheral edema, elevated jugular venous pressure, hepatomegaly, and ascites.  Other findings include hepatojugular reflux, Kussmaul sign (paradoxical increase in jugular venous pressure on inspiration), and pericardial knock (early-diastolic sound).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Constrictive pericarditis

questionList.questionText:
A 34-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with difficulty breathing and dizziness.  An arterial line is placed and her blood pressure tracing is shown below.

Which of the following diagnoses is most consistent with these findings?
questionList.explanationText:
Systemic arterial pressure normally falls <10 mm Hg during inspiration.  However, this patient’s arterial blood pressure tracing shows a fall in systolic pressure >10 mm Hg during inspiration.  This exaggerated drop in blood pressure is referred to as pulsus paradoxus.  It is most commonly seen in patients with cardiac tamponade, which causes increased pressure within the pericardial sac.  As a result, the right and left ventricles are forced to compete with each other for space as they fill with blood (ventricular interdependence).  During inspiration, increased systemic venous return to the right heart causes the interventricular septum to shift into the left ventricular cavity, reducing left ventricular end diastolic volume.  This leads to decreased stroke volume and, consequently, reduced systolic blood pressure.

Pulsus paradoxus can also be caused by other conditions such as asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).  Normally, there is a small variation in intrathoracic pressure with respiration, which drops 2-5 mm Hg below atmospheric pressure during inspiration.  In patients with severe asthma or COPD, the drop in intrathoracic pressure is greatly exaggerated (up to 40 mm Hg).  This negative pressure causes pooling of blood in the pulmonary vasculature decreasing left ventricular preload.  Marked expansion of the lungs in asthma and COPD can also impinge upon the outward expansion of the heart.  Together, these factors lead to an excessive drop in blood pressure that is detected as pulsus paradoxus.

(Choice A)  Significant aortic regurgitation causes a large increase in left ventricular end-diastolic pressure that precludes the interventricular septum from shifting toward the left ventricular cavity during inspiration.  This prevents development of pulsus paradoxus even in the presence of pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade.

(Choices B, C, and D)  Lobar pneumonia, mitral stenosis, and panic attack are not associated with the finding of pulsus paradoxus on physical examination or arterial tracings.

Educational objective:
Pulsus paradoxus is defined as an exaggerated fall in systemic blood pressure >10 mm Hg during inspiration.  It is a frequent finding in cardiac tamponade but can also occur in conditions without pericardial effusion such as severe asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Pulsus paradoxus
